Photocatalytic selective organic transformations coupled with hydrogen (H2) generation under anaerobic conditions is a promising alternative to tackle the challenges of global energy scarcity and green synthesis. In this work, we report the synthesis and application of Ni doped Mn0.25Cd0.75S (MCS-Ni) composites for efficient selective dehydrocoupling of amines into imines and H2. The optimal MCS-Ni composite displays markedly enhanced activities for imines and H2 generation, which are 7.9 and 11.5 times as high as those of pristine MCS, respectively. The Ni doping modulates the electronic structure of MCS, which improves the light-harvesting abilities and inhibits the recombination of photo-generated electron-hole pairs, thereby remarkably improving the photocatalytic performance of the MCS-Ni composite. Furthermore, the electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) technique reveals that carbon centered radicals are the critical intermediates in the amine oxidation reaction. This work is promising to provide inspiration towards the rational construction of metal doped semiconductor composite photocatalysts with effective utilization of photo-generated electrons and holes for the coproduction of clean H2 fuel and high-value added chemicals in a collaborative photoredox reaction. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Mn0.25Cd0.75S Hydrogen evolution Ni doping Imines synthesis Photoredox reaction Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Imines and its derivatives, a kind of functional chemicals containing C=N groups, are the essential intermediates for the synthesis of dyes, biological N-containing compounds and fine chemicals, etc [1–4]. The conventional route for imine synthesis is the condensation of amines with carbonyl compounds, which normally entails unstable dehydrating agents, aldehydes and Lewis acid catalysts [5,6]. An alternative approach is the direct synthesis of imines via the homo-coupling of amines, which has attracted attention for its simple operation, mild reaction conditions and lack of pollutant emissions [7–11]. Therefore, it is desirable to employ semiconductor-based photocatalysts for the photo-driven C–N coupling of amines into imines together with the generation of hydrogen (H2) under anaerobic conditions [12–15]. Metal sulfide semiconductors exhibit excellent activities in a variety of photocatalytic reactions, such as photocatalytic H2 production, organic transformations and CO2 reduction [16,17]. Among them, MnxCd1-xS semiconductors have been extensively studied and their energy band structures can be rationally adjusted by changing the molar ratio of Mn2+/Cd2+ [18–20]. Meanwhile, the presence of Mn2+ can effectively inhibit the photocorrosion of the sulfur-based composites, thus improving the stability of photocatalysts [21]. However, the fast recombination of electrons and holes leads to the low photocatalytic performance of MnxCd1-xS semiconductors [22]. To overcome this challenge, a range of strategies have been developed to facilitate the separation and transfer of photo-generated charge carriers. For example, metal doping is an effective strategy to concurrently modulate the energy band structures, improve light absorption and promote charge transfer efficiencies by introducing impurity energy levels [23–25], which provides promising prospects for the application of MnxCd1-xS in photocatalytic dehydrocoupling of amines to imines. Herein, an efficient photoredox system for the selective dehydrocoupling of benzylamine (BA) into the valued C–N coupling product N-benzylbenzaldimine (NBBA) integrated with H2 production has been constructed on the Ni doped Mn0.25Cd0.75S (MCS-Ni) composite. The modification strategy of Ni doping in MCS can modulate the electron structure of MCS, which effectively increases the light-trapping capabilities and accelerates the photo-generated separation efficiency of electron-hole pairs. Consequently, under visible-light irradiation, the MCS-2%Ni composites exhibit the optimal photocatalytic activities, with the yields of NBBA and H2 that are 7.9 and 11.5 times higher than those of pristine MCS, respectively. In addition, the electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) technique together with in-situ Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy disclose that the production of NBBA occurs through a dehydrocoupling process mediated by the carbon-centered radical intermediates. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals Cadmium acetate dihydrate (Cd(CH3COO)2·2H2O), manganese acetate tetrahydrate (Mn(CH3COO)2·4H2O), nickeldinitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)·6H2O), thioacetamide (CH3CSNH2), triethanolamine (C6H15NO3), acetonitrile (MeCN) and ethanol (EtOH) were provided by Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd (Shanghai, China), 5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrroline-N-oxide (C6H11NO), benzylamine (C7H9N) and N-benzylbenzaldimine (C14H13N) were offered by Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd (Shanghai, China). The deionized water was obtained locally. 2.2 Synthesis 2.2.1 Preparation of blank Mn0.25Cd0.75S (MCS) photocatalyst The synthetic process of blank MCS was on the basis of the previous literature [26]. Primarily, 3 mmol of Cd(CH3COO)2·2H2O was dissolved in 40 mL of deionized water, and then 1 mmol of Mn(CH3COO)2·4H2O and 9 mmol of thioacetamide were added to this solution. Subsequently, the obtained solution was stirred constantly for 1 h. Finally, the hydrothermal reactors were heated in an oven at 200 °C for 24 h. After completion of heating, it was washed by centrifugation several times with deionized water and ethanol and the products were collected. Eventually, the yellow precipitated products obtained were dried in a vacuum oven at 50 °C for one night. 2.2.2 Preparation of Ni doped MCS (MCS-Ni) photocatalyst The synthesis process of MCS-Ni composites (MCS-x%Ni, x represents the theoretical mass ratio of doped Ni, x = 0.5, 1, 2, 3 and 5) was carried out in a similar way to that of blank MCS. The only difference is that after the addition of Cd(CH3COO)2·2H2O, Mn(CH3COO)2·4H2O and thioacetamide, an appropriate amount of Ni(NO3)·6H2O was added into the 40 mL of deionized water. 2.3 Photoactivity testing The photocatalytic dehydrocoupling of benzylamine (BA) into N-benzylbenzaldimine (NBBA) and hydrogen (H2) was carried out in a double-walled quartz reactor. In a typical reaction, 10 mg of photocatalyst samples were added to 10 mL of CH3CN solution containing 0.1 mmol of BA. Besides, the solution was degassed with Ar to remove the air from the reactor before light irradiation. The Xe lamp (PLS-SXE 300D, Beijing Perfectlight Co., Ltd.) was employed as the lighting source and the light energy output was measured as 0.27 W cm-2 (λ > 420 nm). The reaction conditions of the expansion and control experiments were consistent with those of above-mentioned photocatalytic procedures. The liquid phase products were quantified by gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (Shimadzu GC-MS QP 2020, Q-Exactive). The BA conversion (%) is obtained by the formula (n0 – nBA )/n0 × 100 %, and the NBBA selectivity (%) is obtained by the formula 2nNBBA /(n0 – nBA ) × 100 %, where n0 denotes the molar amount of BA initially added to the reaction, nBA and nNBBA represent the molar amount of remaining BA and the molar amount of NBBA produced in the reaction, respectively. 3 Results and discussion The Ni-doped Mn0.25Cd0.75S (MCS-Ni) composite is fabricated by a one-pot hydrothermal method [26], as illustrated in Fig. 1 a. The size and morphological properties of the prepared MCS and MCS-Ni composite have been investigated by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) techniques [16]. As shown in Fig. 1 b-c and Fig. S1a-b, both pristine MCS and MCS-Ni composite exhibit the irregular polyhedral morphology with a non-uniform size distribution ranging from 100 nm to 1 μm, indicating that the doping of Ni does not destroy the morphology of MCS [27]. In addition, the high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image reveals the crystal lattice spacing of 0.318 nm, which pertains to the (002) facet of MCS (Fig. 1 d) [18]. Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) tests indicate that MCS-Ni composite consists of four elements including Mn, Cd, S and Ni (Fig. 1 e). The results of elemental mapping further prove that Ni is uniformly distributed in MCS (Fig. 1 f). In order to explicate the elements composition and valence states of the samples, the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) method has been studied [28]. From the XPS survey spectrum of as-prepared samples, it is clear that the Mn, Cd, S and Ni elements are co-existed in the MCS-Ni composite, which is in accordance with the EDX results (Fig. S2) [29]. As depicted in Fig. 2 a, there are two characteristic peaks centered at 652.28 eV and 641.70 eV in the Mn 2p XPS spectrum, which are attributed to Mn 2p1/2 and Mn 2p3/2 of Mn2+, respectively [22,30]. The XPS spectrum of Cd 3d exhibits two peaks at 411.98 eV and 405.18 eV ascribed to the Cd 3d3/2 and Cd 3d5/2 orbitals of Cd2+, respectively (Fig. 2 b) [21,31]. Moreover, the S 2p spectrum reveals two peaks at 162.95 eV (S 2p1/2) and 161.78 eV (S 2p3/2), indicating the chemical valence state of S element is -2 (Fig. 2 c) [32,33]. As for Ni 2p in MCS-2%Ni composite, the characteristic peaks at 873.38 eV and 855.21 eV belong to the Ni 2p1/2 and Ni 2p3/2 orbitals of Ni2+, respectively (Fig. 2 d) [23]. In addition, the characteristic peaks of Mn 2p, Cd 3d and S 2p in MCS-Ni composites shift to higher binding energies after Ni modification, demonstrating the presence of strong electronic interactions between MCS and Ni [34]. The crystal structures of catalysts have been verified by X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements [35]. Fig. 2 e shows the XRD patterns of blank MCS and MCS-Ni composites with different Ni doping content. Due to the addition of Mn, the diffraction peaks of MCS shift from hexagonal CdS (JCPDS 65–3414) to hexagonal MnS (JCPDS 40–1289), suggesting that MCS semiconductor is a kind of metal sulfide solid solution formed by Mn, Cd and S [26]. The XRD patterns of MCS-Ni composites are almost the same with those of pure MCS owing to the low doping amount of Ni, proving that Ni modification does not disrupt the crystal phase of MCS semiconductor [36]. As indicated in Fig. 2 f, UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS) has been employed to analyze the light absorption properties of the synthesized samples [37,38]. The blank MCS exhibits an intense absorption in the visible region, with an absorption edge at approximately 550 nm [39]. In addition, the absorption intensity of MCS-Ni composite in the visible region is remarkably enhanced after doping Ni in MCS. The photocatalytic selective dehydrocoupling of BA into NBBA coupled with hydrogen (H2) production under visible-light illumination (λ > 420 nm) has been carried out to examine the photocatalytic performance of as-prepared catalysts (Fig. 3 a) [1,40,41]. The gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC–MS) has been conducted to identify the evolution of oxidation products during the reaction (Fig. S3). As demonstrated in Fig. 3 b, the bare MCS shows a relatively low BA conversion rate (11.8 %), along with 5.4 μmol and 4.7 μmol of NBBA and H2 production, respectively. The photocatalytic performance of MCS-Ni composite is greatly enhanced by the modification of MCS with Ni doping. It is evident that the photoactivities of MCS-Ni composites present a volcano-type trend with the increase of Ni doping amount. After 5 h of visible-light irradiation, the MCS-2%Ni composite presents the optimal BA conversion rate (93.9 %), with the NBBA and H2 generation of 46.2 μmol and 45.1 μmol, respectively, which are approximately 7.9 and 11.5 times as high as those of blank MCS. In addition, NBBA exhibits excellent selectivity in this photocatalytic dehydrocoupling process (> 99 %). It is worth noting that the excessive doping of Ni results in the decreased photocatalytic activity of MCS-Ni composite because of the light shielding effect [42]. Furthermore, the molar ratio of imines and H2 production is calculated to be approximately 1:1, indicating that this is a stoichiometric photoredox dehydrocoupling reaction [12]. The time plot indicates that the productions of H2 and NBBA increase with time. After 6 h of irradiation, the NBBA and H2 productions of MCS-2%Ni composites reach 49.3 μmol and 49.1 μmol, respectively, further demonstrating the excellent photocatalytic performance of MCS-2%Ni composite (Fig. 3 c). As presented in Fig. 3 d, the apparent quantum yield (AQY) of NBBA is closely correlated with the wavelength of the incident light and is in accordance with the DRS result of MCS-2%Ni composite. To assess the stability of MCS-2%Ni composite, the recyclability experiments have been conducted. As depicted in Fig. 3 e, the conversion of last cycle only decreases by about 3.4 % compared to the first one, ascribed to the partial loss of the catalyst samples during the recycling experiments, suggesting that the MCS-2%Ni composite possesses excellent photostability. As illustrated in Fig. S4, no significant changes are observed in the XRD spectrum of used MCS-2%Ni composite as compared to the fresh sample, further verifying the excellent stability of as-prepared catalysts [34]. To confirm the general applicability of MCS-2%Ni composite, we have expanded the range of amine substrates. As presented in Table 1 and Figs. S5–7, aromatic amines with different substituents react smoothly to generate the corresponding C–N coupling products with excellent selectivity (> 99 %). It can be noted that there is a discrepancy in the conversion of various aromatic amines, which is due to the difference in substituents and spatial site resistance [43]. The above photocatalytic activity results demonstrate the remarkable photocatalytic performance of MCS-2%Ni composites in the bifunctional reaction for the dehydrocoupling of amines into imines and H2 evolution. To explore the reasons for the improved photocatalytic activities, we have conducted a range of photoelectrochemical experiments over the blank MCS and MCS-2%Ni composite [44]. As shown in Fig. 4 a, the transient photo-current response profiles have been tested via the intermittent light. The markedly enhanced photo-current intensity of the MCS-2%Ni composite in comparison with pristine MCS implies that Ni doping effectively inhibits the recombination of photo-generated electron-hole pairs [45]. Furthermore, to estimate the charge transfer resistance efficiency between the electrolyte and the catalyst contact interface, we have measured the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) of bare MCS and MCS-2%Ni composite. Fig. 4 b displays that the Nyquist plot semi-circle of MCS-2%Ni composite is smaller than that of blank MCS, which indicates a weaker resistance and faster charge transfer between the electrolyte solution and MCS-2%Ni composite [28]. In addition, the linear scanning voltammetry (LSV) curves reveal that Ni doping enhances the current intensity, demonstrating that the doping of Ni remarkably improves the separation efficiency of photo-generated electron-hole pairs and reduces the overpotential of H2 production (Fig. S8) [46]. Therefore, a series of electrochemical measurements demonstrate that Ni doping effectively inhibits the recombination of photo-generated electron-hole pairs, leading to the enhancement of photocatalytic activity for MCS-2%Ni composite. Toward further investigating the behavior of photo-generated charge carriers, we have carried out the steady state photoluminescence (PL) investigation [47]. As demonstrated in Fig. 4 c, both pristine MCS and MCS-2%Ni photocatalysts exhibit characteristic emission peaks at approximately 550 nm. The PL emission peak of MCS-2%Ni composite is significantly lower than that of blank MCS, suggesting that Ni doping effectively promotes the separation and migration rates of photo-generated carriers in MCS-2%Ni composite [48]. Moreover, we have explored the migration dynamics of photo-generated charge carriers by time-resolved photoluminescence (TRPL) spectroscopy [34]. The average emission lifetime (τa) represents the entire emission decay behavior of samples. As illustrated in Fig. 4 d and Table S1, the average lifetime of MCS-2%Ni composite (τa = 3.89 ns) is shorter than that of pristine MCS (τa = 4.72 ns). The decreased decay lifetime substantiates the more efficient charge transfer and migration rates in MCS-2%Ni composite [49]. From the above analysis results, we clarify that Ni modification significantly suppresses the recombination of photo-generated charge carriers, thereby enabling MCS-2%Ni composite with higher photocatalytic performance. To unveil the reaction mechanism of BA dehydrocoupling over MCS-2%Ni composite, we have conducted some controlled experiments under different experimental conditions. Fig. 5 a illuminates the fact that no products are detected in the absence of light or catalyst, showing that the reaction system is a photo-driven catalysis process [34]. The H2 yield exhibits a significant decrease when the photo-generated electron scavenger CCl4 is added to the reaction, revealing that the photo-generated electrons have a crucial role in the H2 generation process [12]. The introduction of hole scavenger triethanolamine (TEOA) markedly restricts the yield of NBBA, implying that the photo-generated holes play the pivotal role in the photocatalytic dehydrocoupling of BA into NBBA [50]. The above-mentioned results confirm that both photoexcited electrons and holes are simultaneously utilized in the formation of H2 and NBBA. In addition, the formation of NBBA is suppressed after the addition of 5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrroline-N-oxide (DMPO) as a radical trapping agent, which suggests that the photocatalytic BA dehydrocoupling is carried out via the radical mechanism [51]. With the purpose of defining the radical intermediates in BA dehydrocoupling process, electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) tests using DMPO as the trapping agents have been conducted. Under dark conditions, no EPR characteristic signal peaks are observed, implicating that the illuminated condition is a prerequisite for the formation of free radical intermediates (Fig. 5 b). With the illumination of light, both blank MCS and MCS-2%Ni composite display six EPR characteristic signal peaks related to free radical intermediate in the BA oxidation process [12]. The quantitative results of EPR spectrum indicate that the values of αH and αN are 22.15 G and 15.70 G, respectively, which authenticate the production of α-aminobenzyl (Ph(•CH)NH2) radical intermediates (Fig. 5 c) [43]. Notably, the peak intensity of MCS-2%Ni composite is significantly stronger than that of pristine MCS, reflecting that Ni doping dramatically facilitates the formation of radical intermediates. To gain insight into the dynamic evolution of the reaction intermediates during BA oxidation reaction, we have performed in-situ Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR). As illustrated in Fig. 5 d, there are two characteristic peaks at 3241 cm−1 and 3337 cm−1 belonging to the symmetric and asymmetric stretching vibrations of N–H bond, respectively [52]. The decrease in the intensity of above-mentioned characteristic peaks indicates the consumption of BA during the oxidation reaction. Meanwhile, the characteristic peak intensity of C=N bond at 1644 cm−1 gradually increases with the prolongation of light irradiation time, which indicates the generation of NBBA [53]. Moreover, the characteristic peaks at 3037 cm−1 and 3078 cm−1 correspond to the stretching vibrations of C–H bonds in benzene ring, and the increase in peak intensity can be attributed to the formation of NBBA [54]. The band structures of semiconductors determine the redox capacities of photo-generated charge carriers and thus play an essential role in the photocatalytic performance of photocatalysts. The band gap energy (Eg) of catalysts has been calculated from the Kubelka-Munk function converted from the DRS spectra [55,56]. As demonstrated in Fig. S9, the measured Eg of MCS-2%Ni composite is 2.25 eV, which is lower than the Eg of blank MCS (2.30 eV). The reduction of Eg contributes to the enhancement of light-harvesting capacity for MCS-2%Ni composite [23]. In addition, we have studied the valence band (VB) positions of blank MCS and MCS-2%Ni composite by the VB-XPS method [34]. As depicted in Fig. S10, the VB values of blank MCS and MCS-2%Ni composite are approximately 1.34 V vs. NHE and 1.48 V vs. NHE, respectively. The increase of VB value contributes to the enhanced oxidizing abilities of photo-generated hole, thereby promoting the photocatalytic dehydrocoupling of BA [23]. The conduction band (CB) positions are calculated to be −0.96 V vs. NHE and −0.77 V vs. NHE for blank MCS and MCS-2%Ni composite, respectively [57]. From the foregoing discussion, it is concluded that the Ni doping endows MCS-2%Ni composite with the optimized photoredox ability, enhanced photo-capture capacity and increased photo-generated carrier separation ability [58]. Building on the above results, a rational reaction mechanism for the photocatalytic dehydrocoupling of BA over MCS-2%Ni composite is presented in Fig. 5 e. Under visible-light illumination, the photo-generated electrons and holes are formed in MCS. The Ni sites achieve the efficient separation of photo-generated charge carriers by capturing photo-generated electrons. The photo-generated holes first attack BA to produce the PhCH2NH2 •+ cations, which are then transformed into the Ph(•CH)NH2 radical intermediates by deprotonation. Subsequently, the Ph(•CH)NH2 radicals are further attacked by photo-generated holes to form the nucleophilic PhCHNH, which then interacts with the other BA molecule to generate the C–N coupling product NBBA. At the same time, the protons detached from the BA are adsorbed on the Ni sites and are eventually reduced to H2 by photo-generated electrons. 4 Conclusion In summary, we demonstrate the preparation and application of Ni doped MCS composites (MCS-Ni) for the visible-light-driven dehydrocoupling of BA into NBBA with concomitant H2 evolution. The optimal MCS-Ni composite displays significantly enhanced photocatalytic performance for the productions of NBBA and H2 compared to blank MCS, along with the superior selectivity of NBBA (> 99 %). Mechanistic studies unveil that Ni doping alters the electronic structure of MCS-Ni photocatalyst, leading to the efficient separation of photo-generated electron-hole pairs, improved light absorption and optimized photoredox abilities. This work could open new vistas for the rational design of transition metal-doped semiconductor photocatalysts toward concurrently producing high-value chemicals and H2 fuel in a cooperative system via simultaneous and efficient utilization of photo-generated electrons and holes. coredata.dc:description: Photocatalytic selective organic transformations coupled with hydrogen (H2) generation under anaerobic conditions is a promising alternative to tackle the challenges of global energy scarcity and green synthesis. In this work, we report the synthesis and application of Ni doped Mn0.25Cd0.75S (MCS-Ni) composites for efficient selective dehydrocoupling of amines into imines and H2. The optimal MCS-Ni composite displays markedly enhanced activities for imines and H2 generation, which are 7.9 and 11.5 times as high as those of pristine MCS, respectively. The Ni doping modulates the electronic structure of MCS, which improves the light-harvesting abilities and inhibits the recombination of photo-generated electron-hole pairs, thereby remarkably improving the photocatalytic performance of the MCS-Ni composite. Furthermore, the electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) technique reveals that carbon centered radicals are the critical intermediates in the amine oxidation reaction. This work is promising to provide inspiration towards the rational construction of metal doped semiconductor composite photocatalysts with effective utilization of photo-generated electrons and holes for the coproduction of clean H2 fuel and high-value added chemicals in a collaborative photoredox reaction.
